Magazine Focuses on People's Personal Experiences
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When families lived together, older people were a link between the past and future, reminiscing about the history they'd lived. Today, families are far-flung and often out of touch, but the need for a link remains. ``One of the important lessons of the book `Roots' is that family and society are enormously interested in the past experiences of individuals that they know,'' said Dr. Gene Cohen, a psychiatrist and deputy director of the National Institute on Aging. ``Look at how excited people are to look at old photo albums. That's a form of reminiscing.'' ``A lot of people have stories in them, but they haven't written them down because there's just no place for their writing to appear,'' said Jay Thomas Collins who, with partner William Michaelian, offers just such a forum. The two in May 1988 launched Harvest, a literary magazine featuring the reminiscences of people over 50. Michaelian, 33, and Collins, 29, who both grew up in storytelling families, aren't interested in family histories that merely list the comings and goings of a particular family or group of people. Harvest is filled mainly with the remembrances of everyday people whose good times and bad times preceded shopping malls, freeways and fast-food restaurants. The bimonthly magazine has grown in circulation to about 1,500 and gets about 40 or 50 submissions a week from around the country. Harvest doesn't pay, but people whose articles are published get 10 free copies. Some stories are sent by professionals, but most writers have never had anything published. ``We're looking for stories that really have something to say. Whether it's polished or not is not our major concern. We just want to present simple, honest stories,'' Michaelian said. ``We look for something that has lasting meaning to someone's life,'' Collins said. ``There used to be a role for older people as storytellers. They used to be valued for that. They've been through good times and bad times. They have perspective, and some of their reflections can teach you a great deal.'' Consider ``Thanksgiving 1930,'' a story in the November-December issue. Albert Bessler recalls waiting for several days during the Depression to get a free food basket from the Salvation Army. Bessler describes huddling with his brothers and sister in the family's Model T to keep warm after their meal: ``When you're in a warm place and your belly is full and you have someone to hold, what more could you want? I was thankful for Thanksgiving Day. I was satisfied. I had a good deal.'' Such reminiscences offer younger people new perspectives _ ``they invariably derive new insights about themselves'' _ while being a healthy experience for older people, Cohen said. ``For a number of people, it can be a very helpful and therapeutic process that brings them back to a broader perspective in terms of what their life has been. ``The past has undoubtedly contained a number of situations which at the time might have seemed insurmountable but yet we found that we've gotten over them. Those reminders are very important to help restore someone's perspective on the present.''
Harvest's address: 2322 Latona Drive NE, Salem, OR 97303.
